snippet.title: Huge drug lab lands dad to jail
snippet.content: A "FAMILY man" has been jailed for more than seven years over a huge rural drug laboratory and ordered to serve a suspended sentence for attempting to pervert the course of justice in a murder investigation. Amadeo Macchiavelli pleaded guilty to drug trafficking charges over the discovery of an in the Murraylands in February 2014. Police found more than 190,000 ecstasy and NBOMe tablets, a pill press and precursor drugs capable of manufacturing $50 million worth of methamphetamine. The 34-year old also pleaded guilty to a further drug trafficking charge over a separate July 2014 raid which uncovered a large amount of pure methamphetamine and cutting agents at a Croydon Park property which he rented. District Court judge Rauf Soulio said that despite the magnitude of the Walker Flat drug haul, he accepted Macchiavelli was "mid-range" player in the scheme. "You were not a financier or organiser of the operation but were rather a guaranteed purchaser of some of the resulting product," Judge Soulio said. Macchiavelli must also serve a six-month sentence for attempting to pervert the course of justice over the investigation into the 2012 . Macchiavelli admitted he cleaned his luxury silver Porsche before police could examine it following Mr Hatzis' death outside a Light Square nightclub. Macchiavelli, who was described as a "family man" in glowing character references, received a total head sentence of seven years and six months but could be released on parole by Christmas next year.
